text: well it was quite volatile when we were
there David we were there when the the
vote was announced that the first
reading of these amendments or this
amendment to the Constitution granting
more autonomy to regions that this had
passed now it should be emphasized as
just the first amendment there's a
second amendment that will be or sorry a
second reading that will be voted on
later but the reaction to the news of
this of this first vote was very much
negative very passionate the crowd
shouting shame and then they moved on to
the line of the of the riot police there
where we saw clashes apparently pepper
spray smoke bombs were hurled and it was
indeed it was a very tense situation
while we were there we left a little bit
later it seemed to be quieting down in
fact in some of the computers some of
the crowded left but at just five
minutes after we left apparently there
was another there was an explosion there
now a colleague from the BBC Ukrainian
service was there when the explosion
took place he said he heard three
smaller explosions what could have been
stun grenades or stun bombs and then a
larger one and he saw people being he
saw ambulance show up and then also the
riot police the National Guard being
taken out he saw a number of injured two
people seriously we've also heard from
the press service of the National Guard
they say that dozens were injured and
four are four people of therefore the
National Guard are in serious condition
right David is it possible to sort of
characterize who the protesters are what
they're do they have a particular
political affiliation didn't give us a
bit of detail well exactly well the the
demonstration was to a large degree led
by the swaboda that's the freedom party
which is a ultra nationalist party but
there were other groups among them
difficult to say all the people there
there were lots of flags I mean it was a
group of about 2,000 I would say at its
peak they are very critical of the of
the vote there was also another party
there known as the radical party which
is led by a by a politician by name a
lady
now it's not clear how much support they
actually have among Ukrainian society as
a whole but they themselves are very
much dead set against these against
these amendments they blocked the the
rostrum the the speaker's platform in
Parliament and they were equally very
passionate and volatile scenes in
Parliament prior to the vote but as we
said the vote did pass with a pretty
comfortable margin
